This gon' cut down on them accidents with mopeds and folks walking around. Look at Torseau Island next door – they had half as many moped crashes last year 'cause they put caps on the rentals. So if we wanna drop our accident rates
column7: we gotta do the same thing in the summer.""

column1: Now
column2: let's break down what's really behind all that talk. We gotta look at whether their thinking holds up and what it means for the argument if things ain't really like they say.";"""The population on Balmer Island double during the summer months. During the summer
column3: then
column4: the town council of Balmer Island should decrease the maximum number of moped rentals allowed at each of the island's six moped and bicycle rental companies from 50 per day to 30 per day. This will significantly reduce the number of summertime accidents involving mopeds and pedestrians. The neighboring island of Torseau actually saw a 50 percent reduction in moped accidents last year when Torseau's town council enforced similar limits on moped rentals. To help reduce moped accidents
column5: therefore
column6: we should also enforce those limitations during the summer months.""

column1: This argument relies on several key assumptions. Firstly
column2: it assumes that the main cause of summertime accidents on Balmer Island is the high number of moped rentals. Secondly
column3: it assumes that what worked for Torseau will work for Balmer Island
column4: failing to consider potential differences in traffic patterns
column5: road conditions
column6: or other factors that may affect the effectiveness of the moped rental limitations. Thirdly
column7: the argument assumes that reducing moped rentals will automatically lead to a decrease in accidents
column8: overlooking the possibility of other contributing factors.

column1: If these assumptions are proven to be unwarranted
column2: the argument's effectiveness would be greatly compromised. For instance
column3: if the primary cause of accidents is found to be inexperienced riders rather than simply the number of mopeds on the road
column4: then limiting rentals may not address the root issue. Additionally
column5: if Balmer Island has different terrain or infrastructure compared to Torseau
column6: the success experienced by Torseau may not necessarily translate to Balmer Island. Therefore
column7: a more comprehensive analysis of the causes of accidents and tailored solutions may be needed to effectively reduce moped accidents on Balmer Island."

column3: check this out

column5: can they really deliver? Once we know all this

column7: you feel me?";"A recent sales study indicates that consumption of seafood dishes in Bay City restaurants has increased by 30 percent during the past five years. Yet there are no currently operating city restaurants whose specialty is seafood. Moreover
column8: the majority of families in Bay City are two-income families

column3: understanding the pricing strategy of the new restaurant would help evaluate its competitiveness in a market where no seafood-specialty restaurants currently operate."

column1: So the city council in Dillton was all about gettin' new gigs to the hood and giving that slow economy a boost

column4: Dillton got two new factories on the block. Even though these spots got over a thousand heads on the payroll

column6: not the Dillton crew.

column1: Now
column2: let me holla at you with some other reasons why the numbers might be what they are
column3: you feel me? Let's break down some other ways this could be playing out.";"In an effort to bring new jobs to Dillton and stimulate the city's flagged economy
column4: Dillton's city council voted last year to lower the city's corporate tax rate by 15 percentage; at the same time
column5: the city began offering generous relocation grants to any company that would move to Dillton. Since these changes went into effect
column6: two new factories have opened in Dillton. Although the two factories employ over 1
column7: 000 people
column8: the unemployment rate in Dillton remains unchanged. The only clear explanation for this is that the new factories are staff with out-of-town workers rather than Dillton residents.

column1: One possible alternative explanation could be that the job market in Dillton is not diverse enough to support the skilled labor needed for the new factories. As a result
column2: the factories might have had to look beyond Dillton for qualified employees. Additionally
column3: inadequate training programs in Dillton could have led to a mismatch between the skills required by the new factories and those possessed by the local residents. This could explain why the unemployment rate has not decreased despite the new job opportunities.

column1: Furthermore
column2: it is essential to consider the possibility that other economic factors in Dillton
column3: such as competition from neighboring cities or the overall state of the national economy
column4: are influencing the unemployment rate. If Dillton is facing external economic challenges that outweigh the benefits of the new factories
column5: it could explain why the unemployment rate persists despite the increase in job openings.

column1: Thus
column2: while the argument presented attributes the unchanged unemployment rate solely to the employment of out-of-town workers
column3: considering factors like local skill shortages and broader economic conditions provides a more comprehensive understanding of the situation in Dillton."

column1: Answering these questions gon";"""In a recent study more than 5
column2: 000 adolescents were asked how often they ate meals with their families. Almost 30 percent of the teens said they ate at least seven meals per week with their families. Furthermore

column7: low self-esteem
column8: and depression. We therefore recommend that families have as many meals together as possible. We predict that doing so will greatly benefit adolescents and turn troubled teens away from bad behaviors.""

column1: It would be essential to answer several inquiries to assess the reliability of the recommendation made in the newsletter. One question would be about the sample size of the study. Were the 5
column2: 000 adolescents from a diverse range of backgrounds
column3: or were they from a specific demographic
column4: like one school or region? Understanding the diversity of the participants would help determine if the results can be generalized to a broader population.

column2: or was it merely an association? Clarifying this distinction would help in understanding if having more family meals directly leads to the mentioned benefits.

column1: Lastly
column2: the methodological approach of the survey needs clarification. How were the data collected
column3: and were there any potential biases in the survey design? Knowing the methodology would provide insights into the reliability and validity of the results presented.

column1: By answering these questions
column2: we can better evaluate the recommendation's validity and determine whether increasing family meals truly has the predicted positive impact on adolescents."""

column2: check this out: Some new research on like eighteen rhesus monkeys out there droppin' hints 'bout how bein' born first or later can mess wit' how pumped an individual be. This here study tell us that when stuff gets wild
column3: like bumpin' into a monkey they ain't ever met
column4: them firstborn baby monkeys be churnin' out 'bout twice the cortisol—that's the get-up-and-go hormone—compared to they little bros and sis'. Firstborn humans
column5: they get that cortisol poppin' off too

column7: ya know

column1: A'ight
column2: so let's chop it up 'bout some other ways to spit what all this might mean. What's another angle that could explain the same set of facts
column3: but from a different playbook? We gotta think on how any fresh theory we throw down can still fit snug with what's been laid out by the study.";"Dear Editor

column1: I have read with interest the recent study involving eighteen rhesus monkeys
column2: which discusses the impact of birth order on an individual's stimulation levels. It came to my attention that there are several aspects of the research that may benefit from alternative perspectives.

column1: First and foremost
column2: one may want to consider that the levels of cortisol produced by firstborn infant monkeys could be influenced by factors other than birth order. For instance
column3: the diet of the monkeys or their genetic predispositions could also play a role in the differences observed. Therefore
column4: it is critical to not leap to conclusions solely based on birth order as the explanatory factor.

column1: In addition
column2: the study suggests that first-time mother monkeys have higher cortisol levels during pregnancy compared to those who have had multiple offspring. However
column3: a potential mistake may lie in assuming that cortisol levels are solely determined by the number of offspring a mother has had. It is conceivable that external factors
column4: such as environmental stressors or social interactions
column5: could significantly impact cortisol levels during pregnancy.

column1: Furthermore
column2: the comparison drawn between firstborn infant monkeys and their younger siblings in stimulating situations may overlook individual variations within each group. It is possible that personality traits or prior experiences could influence how monkeys
column3: irrespective of birth order
column4: respond to unfamiliar situations and consequently
column5: produce varying amounts of cortisol.

column1: In conclusion
column2: while the study raises intriguing points about the relationship between birth order and stimulation levels
column3: it is essential to critically evaluate alternative explanations and consider the complexity of factors at play. By doing so
column4: a more comprehensive understanding of the findings can be achieved.

column1: Sincerely
[Your Name]"

column1: I read with interest your concerns regarding the decline in foot traffic at Central Plaza and the increase in skateboarding's popularity. It is true that the number of shoppers has been decreasing
column2: while the number of skateboarders has dramatically increased over the past two years. Some Central Plaza store owners believe that the decreased business can be attributed to the skateboard users in the plaza. Another issue that has been raised is the rise in littering and vandalism in the area. As a result
column3: your suggestion to prohibit skateboarding in Central Plaza has been put forward. If skateboarding is to be disallowed
column4: it is predicted that business in the Plaza will flourish once more.

column1: To better assess the viability of this recommendation
column2: several questions need to be addressed. Firstly
column3: it is crucial to determine if the decrease in shoppers is directly linked to the increased presence of skateboarders. Secondly
column4: what measures will be taken to address the littering and vandalism issues
column5: even if skateboarding is banned? Additionally
column6: it is essential to understand the impact of such a ban on the overall community and whether it might lead to unintended consequences.

column1: Clarifying these aspects will provide crucial insights into the potential effectiveness of prohibiting skateboarding in Central Plaza. Thank you for bringing attention to this matter.
Sincerely
[Your Name]"

column1: The errors infused into the text are:
1. **""apperared""** - Error: Misspelling. Correction: 'appeared'
2. **""two times higher as of Fitch""** - Error: Mistake in comparative structure. Correction: 'twice as high as that of Fitch'
3. **""home sells""** - Error: Incorrect pluralization. Correction: 'home sales'
4. **""sell more quickly""** - Error: Incorrect comparative form. Correction: 'sell faster'
5. **""it took over four months""** - Error: Incorrect preposition. Correction: 'it took more than four months to sell'
6. **""took only one months""** - Error: Subject-verb agreement. Correction: 'it took only one month'
Ensure to always double check your grammar and spelling to communicate clearly."

column4: nah mean?";"In the letter to the editor of the Balmer Island Gazette
column5: an argument is made that the town council should reduce the number of moped rentals to 25 per day during the summer months to decrease accidents. However
column6: several questions should be posed to evaluate this recommendation effectively.

column1: Firstly
column2: it is essential to question if reducing the number of moped rentals truly simulates a significant decreasement in accidents. Without sufficient data
column3: it is challenging to determine if this correlation guarantees causation. For example
column4: what were the primary causes of accidents on Balmer Island
column5: and how does this compare to Seaville? This will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the situation.

column1: Secondly
column2: it is imperative to inquire about the specifics of the accidents to assess if the proposed solution directly addresses the root cause. Understanding the circumstances in which accidents occur
column3: such as the involvement of pedestrians or specific locations prone to incidents
column4: will help determine if the limitation on moped rentals is the most effective approach.

column1: Lastly
column2: it is critical to examine the feasibility and implication of such a policy. How will the reduction in moped rentals impact the local economy and tourism on Balmer Island? Will this affect the livelihoods of local residents who rely on moped rental businesses for income? Considering these aspects is essential to ensure a balanced decision-making process.

column1: By addressing these questions
column2: a more comprehensive evaluation of the recommendation can be achieved. It is important to analyze the situation from various angles to make an informed decision that considers all stakeholders involved."

They search for food by moving over ice from island to island during the course of the year. Their habitat is limited to areas warm enough to sustain the plants on which they feed and cold enough
column3: at least some of the year
column4: for the ice to cover the sea separating the islands
column5: allowing the deer to travel over it. Sadly

column8: we can conclude that the purported decline in deer populations is the result of the deer's being unable to follow their age-old migration patterns across the frozen sea.

column1: So Dr. Karp's like
column2: ""Hol' up

column1: Some of these 'thropology heads are now sayin' we gotta keep on with them interviews to really get the lowdown on how Tertian kids get brought up.
Now

column1: We also gotta peep how Dr. Field did his thing back in the day—was his watch game strong enough to really see the whole picture? Plus

column3: and things done changed since.

column1: Answering all that? Yeah
column2: that'll help us see if hittin' up more interviews is the slick move for diggin' into how Tertian kids grow up.";"Twenty years ago
column3: Dr. Field
column4: a noted anthropologist
column5: visited the island of Tertia.  U sing an observation-centered approach to studying Tertian culture
column6: he concluded from his observations that  childs  in Tertia were reared by an  whole  village  rather than by their own biological parents. Recently
column7: another anthropologist
column8: Dr. Karp
column9: visited the group of islands that includes Tertia and used the interview-centered method to study child-rearing practices. In the interviews that Dr. Karp conducted with children  who  living in this group of islands
column10: the children spent much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. Dr. Karp decided that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture must be invalid. Some anthropologists  recommends  that to obtain accurate information on Tertian child-rearing practices
column11: future research on the subject should be conducted via the interview-centered method.

column1: To evaluate the recommendation and the argument on which it is based
column2: several questions would need to be answered. Firstly
column3: it is important to ask how many participants were involved in the research conducted by Dr. Karp. This would help determine the generalizability of the findings to the entire village of Tertia. Secondly
column4: it is crucial to inquire about the age range of the children interviewed by Dr. Karp. Understanding whether the interviews included a diverse range of ages could shed light on the consistency of the reported child-rearing practices. Additionally
column5: it would be essential to inquire about the specific questions asked during the interviews to ascertain the depth of information gathered about the role of the entire village in raising children. Answering these questions would provide insights into the validity of the recommendation to use the interview-centered method for future research on Tertian child-rearing practices."

column1: Alright

column1: First off
column2: we gotta ask

column4: ya know?

column1: Then
column2: we gotta peep the real deal about what Satellite Waste Corporation be doin' or ain't doin' right. Is the trash situation all on them or is there more to the story?

column1: Also
column2: was Arko really keepin' things that clean
column3: or is Ocean Harbor's beach just naturally more poppin' for some other reasons?

column1: Now
column2: don't forget
column3: we need to check the green too. Is switchin' back to Arko gon' hit our pockets hard? What's the cost look like compared to Satellite?

column1: Lastly

column3: or do we need to step up our game in other areas too?

column1: Answers to all this gonna help us figure if the city manager's idea is solid or if we need to come at this from a different angle
column2: ya dig?";"The following is a recommendation from the city manager of Bridge Bay:

column1: Last year
column2: the number of visits to our local beach in Bridge Bay was 50 percent lower than the year before. Early last year we ended our contract with Arko Trash Collection
column3: a company that had serviced local garbage collection for the past twenty years. We switched at that time to Satellite Waste Corporation
column4: another trash collection company. In nearby Ocean Harbor
column5: where Arko has continued to provide garbage selection
column6: the beaches are experiencing record levels of attendance. Meanwhile
column7: in Bridge Bay
column8: complaints about the garbage on our beach have increased this year. Clearly
column9: inadequate garbage collection on our beach by Satellite has led to the significant drop in visitors. Therefore
column10: in order to restore visitor numbers to our local beach
column11: we recommend resuming our contract with Arko as soon as possible.""

column1: In responding to this recommendation
column2: there are some crucial questions that need to be answered to ascertain its validity:

column1: 1. What were the specific reasons for terminating the contract with Arko Trash Collection and switching to Satellite Waste Corporation? Without understanding the underlying motivations
column2: it is challenging to determine if reverting to Arko is the best solution.

column1: 2. How does the quality and efficiency of garbage collection between Arko Trash Collection and Satellite Waste Corporation compare? It is necessary to assess whether the decrease in visitor numbers is directly linked to the inadequacy of the new service provider.
3. Are there other factors beyond garbage collection that could have contributed to the drop in visitors
column2: such as changes in tourism trends or economic conditions? Examining the broader context can help in evaluating the impact of garbage collection on beach attendance accurately.

column1: By addressing these inquiries
column2: we can better evaluate the recommendation to resume the contract with Arko Trash Collection and determine if it is the most effective course of action for improving visitor numbers to the local beach in Bridge Bay."

column1: On this year's survey about work habits
column2: our employees tended to strongly agree with the idea that if they took less time to complete their assigned work
column3: the quality of their work would suffer. However
column4: we recently conducted an internal study that disproves this idea wrong. Managers acros several divisions identified an overtime group: the employees who worked an average of 48 or more hours per week over the past year instead of the expected 40 hours per week. We then looked at the number of documented work errors produced by all of our employees during the past year and found that the overtime group was responsible for significantly more work errors overall than their fellow employees. On the basis of this findings
column5: our recommendation to the company president is to require employees at Dexter Gorman Instruments to complete their work during the regular 40-hour work week and allow overtime only for urgent circumstances.""

""Motilac is a substance that occurs naturally in the human digestive tract. Many consumers of dietary supplements containing motilac report significant easing of digestive discomfort after just a few weeks of use. Among Greenhorne residents
column4: the consumption of motilac supplements has increased 80% over the last seven years. Last year
column5: Greenhorne's five hospitals reported fewer cases of serious gastrointestinal disorders than any year on record. Meanwhile
column6: sales of motilac supplements are declining in the neighboring town of Etolin. Notably
column7: hospitals in Etolin report a steady increase in the last two years in patients experiencing a wide range of distressing gastrointestinal symptoms. The clear explanation of these trends is that motilac is effective in preventing many serious gastrointestinal disorders.""

column1: Alternative Explanations:
One factor worth considering is that the data from Greenhorne may be incomplete or not entirely reliable
column2: as it only takes into account the number of reported cases and not the severity of each case. Therefore
column3: it is possible that there is underreporting of serious gastrointestinal disorders
column4: leading to a skewed perspective on the effectiveness of motilac supplements. Moreover
column5: the increase in consumption of motilac in Greenhorne may be due to aggressive marketing strategies rather than the actual efficacy of the product. Additionally
column6: differences in lifestyle habits between Greenhorne and Etolin residents
column7: such as diet or exercise patterns
column8: could contribute to the varying rates of gastrointestinal symptoms seen in the two towns. These factors cast doubt on the assertion that motilac is solely responsible for the observed trends."

column1: Firstly

column3: so check it

Now they sayin' those firms where the big dogs say they only need like six hours max of sleep be gettin' more dough and blowin' up quicker. So they droppin' the idea that if you tryna make your biz flourish

column1: Let's break down what's under the hood of what they assumin' though. First off
column2: we gotta peep whether sleep really play a role like that in how well a firm do. We need to know if it's causation or just correlation
column3: ya feel me? Just 'cause these execs sleep less
column4: don't exactly mean that's the magic pill for success.

column1: Then
column2: there's the assumption that you can just straight up measure success by profit margins and growth
column3: but what 'bout other stuff like employee happiness
column4: customer satisfaction
column5: or sustainability? They ain't even touch on none of that.

column1: Plus
column2: what if these execs be cappin' 'bout how much they sleep or there's other things at play

column1: So
column2: this argument got some holes in it
column3: right? It's leanin' on these assumptions that if they don't hold up
column4: the whole thing could fall apart. If the sleep thing ain't really what's driving success
column5: then we might be missin' out on some good hires just 'cause they like to get their full eight hours. We gotta look deeper before we start sayin' less sleep is the secret sauce to making it big.";"""A recent study rating 300 male and female Mentian advertising executives according to the average number of hours they sleep per night showed an association between the amount of sleep the executives need and the success of their firms. Of the advertising firms studied
column6: those whose executives reported needing no more than 6 hours of sleep per night had higher profit margins and faster growth. These results suggest that if a business wants to prosper
column7: it should hire only people who need no more than 6 hours of sleep per night.""

column1: Response:
When examining the argument presented in the article
column2: it is crucial to identify the assumptions made by the author and evaluate their validity. Firstly
column3: the assumption that the success of advertising firms is solely dependent on the sleep duration of their executives is too simplistic. Success in business is a multi-faceted concept that involves various factors beyond just sleep patterns. Secondly
column4: the argument relies on the assumption that causation can be inferred from the correlation observed between executives' sleep duration and profitability. However
column5: correlation does not necessarily imply causation
column6: and there may exist other variables influencing the results. Lastly
column7: the argument suggests a blanket statement that businesses should hire individuals who require less than 6 hours of sleep per night to prosper. This assumption overlooks the individual differences in sleep needs and productivity levels
column8: which can vary greatly among people. If these assumptions are proven unwarranted
column9: the implications for the argument would be significant. It would undermine the validity of the conclusion drawn and highlight the need for a more comprehensive analysis of the factors contributing to business success."

column1: 154;"Some people believe that traveling to and living in numerous places increases one's ability to relate and connect to other people. Others believe that this ability is better cultivated by living in one place and developing a deep understanding of that community.
Write a response in which you discuss which view more closely aligns with your own position and explain your reasoning for the position you take. In developing and supporting your position
column2: you should address both of the views presented.";analyze_an_issue;https://web.archive.org/web/20220324020435/https://www.ets.org/gre/revised_general/prepare/analytical_writing/issue/pool;" 'Bout twenty years back
column3: Dr. Field
column4: this big-time anthropologist
column5: rolled up to Tertia island and after peepin' the scene
column6: dude comes to the conclusion that the whole village was bringin' up them kids
column7: not just they own moms and pops. But now
column8: check it
column9: I been hollering at the youngins in the island group
column10: including Tertia
column11: and what I'm hearin' is they talkin' 'bout they biological folks way more than any other grown folks in the village. So what I'm sayin' is my research be layin' out that Dr. Field's take on Tertian village culture ain't holding up
column12: and all that means is this whole method where you just watch folks to learn 'bout cultures ain't cutting it neither. Me and my grad student squad
column13: we using this interview game now in Tertia
column14: and believe me
column15: this is gonna drop some real talk on how child-rearing go down over there and in other island spots.

column1: Now if y'all tryna size up my argument
column2: you gonna need some solid evidence
column3: feel me? First off
column4: you gotta have more than just my word on how them kids talk 'bout their folks – we need stats
column5: recordings
column6: all that good stuff to show the real picture. Then
column7: you gotta see if the way kids talk about their folks match up with how they actually roll with 'em. Like
column8: do they spend time with their biological parents more than with other adults? Plus
column9: you can't just listen to the kids; you gotta check in with the parents
column10: the neighbors
column11: the whole village to really get that full view.

column1: Now if the evidence show that the kids really do be getting raised by the village
column2: then my argument ain't holding water. But if it turn out the biological parents are the main ones doing the raising
column3: then
column4: yeah
column5: it's a slam dunk for my interview method and a straight fade on Dr. Field's watching game. That's how it is.""";"The following appeared in an article written by Dr. Karp
column6: an anthropologist.

column1: Twenty years ago
column2: Dr. Field
column3: a noted anthropologist
column4: visited the island of Tertia and concluded from his observations that children in Tertia were reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. However
column5: my recent interviews with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia show that these children spend much more talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. This research of mine proves that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture is invalid and thus that the observation-centered approach to study cultures is invalid as well. The interview-centered method that my team of graduate students is currently using in Tertia will establish a much more accurately understanding of child-rearing traditions there and in other island cultures.""

column1: In this article by Dr. Karp
column2: there are several errors that could affect the argument's clarity and effectiveness. Firstly
column3: the phrase ""much more talking about their biological parents"" should be corrected to ""much more time talking about their biological parents"" to improve the sentence's coherence.

column1: Moreover
column2: the phrase ""establish a much more accurately understanding"" contains a common ESL error
column3: using ""accurately"" as an adverb instead of the correct form ""accurate."" The correct phrase should be ""establish a much more accurate understanding.""

column1: Lastly
column2: the phrasing ""to study cultures is invalid as well"" presents a common ESL error in the use of ""as well."" A better phrasing would be ""to study cultures is also invalid.""

column1: By addressing these errors
column2: the argument would have clearer communication and a stronger impact on the reader
column3: enhancing the overall effectiveness of the article."

column5: Groveton College done cut down on all that mess by bringing in an honor code. This code got students promising not to cheat and to holla at a professor if they peep someone else doin' shady. Before all that
column6: teachers had to be all up in students' business
column7: and they used to catch like thirty folks cheatin' every year. Once they rolled out this honor code
column8: first year students snitched on twenty-one cheaters; then five years down the line
column9: them numbers fell to just fourteen. On top of that
column10: most students at Groveton say they ain't as likely to cheat if there's an honor code. So
column11: the word is
column12: all colleges should get like Groveton to get that cheating down.

column1: Yo
column2: if we gon' talk bout whether this whole idea good or not
column3: we gotta ask some real questions. First off
column4: we need to know what's really good with this report talking bout cheating going up. Like
column5: what kind of cheating they talking about? And how they know it's really going up? Next
column6: we gotta figure out if Groveton's honor code is the only reason they got less cheaters
column7: or if something else is at play. Was there something else they did at the same time they brought in the honor code?

column1: Then we need to dig into how they keep track of cheating. Are students just scared to report now
column2: or they really respect the code? We also gotta see what's up with them surveys — you know
column3: who they asking
column4: how they asking
column5: and if everybody keeping it a hundred. 'Cause if students just saying what they think folks wanna hear
column6: that ain't gonna tell us much.

column1: We also can't just assume what worked at Groveton gonna work everywhere else. Different school
column2: different vibe
column3: you know? What's making them Groveton kids stick to the code might not fly at another spot. So
column4: we gotta see if there's something special bout Groveton that helped that honor code do its thing.

column1: Answering these questions gonna help us figure if this honor code move makes sense for other schools. 'Cause we gotta know if it really gets to the heart of why students cheat and if it's versatile enough to work at all types of colleges and universities.";"I believes that according to a most recent report
column2: cheating among college and university students are increasing. Nevertheless
column3: Groveton College has success reduced student cheating by adopting an honor code
column4: which calls for students to agree not to cheat in their academic endeavors and to notify a faculty member if they suspicions that others have cheated. Groveton's honor code replaced a system in which teachers closely monitoring students; under that system
column5: teachers reported an average of thirty cases of cheating per year. In the first year the honor code was in place
column6: students reported twenty-one cases of cheating; five years later
column7: this figuer had dropped to fourteen. Moreover
column8: in a recent survey
column9: a majority of Groveton students said that they would be less likely to cheating with an honor code in place than without. Therefore
column10: all colleges and universities should adopting honor codes similar to Groveton's in order to decrease cheating among students.

column1: If one were to critically examines the recommendation made in the text
column2: several key questions must be addressed to ascertain its reasonability. Firstly
column3: what specific measures did Groveton College put in place to implement and enforce the honor code? Secondly
column4: how were the cases of cheating identified and reported by the students verified to ensure their accuracy? Lastly
column5: what factors
column6: besides the honor code
column7: could have contributed to the decrease in reported cheating cases over the years?

column1: By obtaining answers to these questions
column2: we can better evaluate the strength of the recommendation and the argument supporting it. This
column3: in turn
column4: will provide a more comprehensive understanding of whether adopting honor codes akin to Groveton's is truly an effective measure to combat student cheating in colleges and universities."

column1: 156;"The following appeared in an article written by Dr. Karp
column2: an anthropologist.

column1: Twenty years ago
column2: Dr. Field
column3: a noted anthropologist
column4: visited the island of Tertia and concluded from his observations that children in Tertia were reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. However
column5: my recent interviews with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia show that these children spend much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. This research of mine proves that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture is invalid and thus that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is invalid as well. The interview-centered method that my team of graduate students is currently using in Tertia will establish a much more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions there and in other island cultures.""

column1: Now

column1: One thing we gotta consider is there might just be way more people out there ridin' bikes these days. Like

column3: naturally
column4: you gonna see more accidents
column5: feel me? That don’t mean folks are wildin' out more just 'cause they got helmets.

column1: Another thing
column2: what if the streets ain't safe as they used to be? Maybe we got more cars
column3: or the driving's worse
column4: or the roads ain't kept up right. That could crank up the accident numbers too
column5: right? It ain't necessarily about the bikers changing up how they ride.

column1: And yo
column2: what about them bikes huh? Bikes might be built different now
column3: faster or trickier to handle. If the bikes got more zip or ain't as sturdy
column4: that could be why more folks is crashing even if they got their dome protected.

column1: So you see
column2: it ain't just about feeling safe in helmets and takin' more chances. We gotta scope out all angles if we tryna get to the bottom of why there's more bike accidents happening. Gotta look at the bigger picture
column3: ya know?";"The following memo was published by the Welzaton City Commission. ""A recent nationwide study of the effectiveness of wearing a safety helmet while bicycling indicates that ten yaers ago approximately 35 percent of all bicyclists reported wearing helmets
column4: whereas today that number is nearly 80 percent. Another studie
column5: however
column6: sited a 200 percent increase in the number of serious accidents involving bicycles during the same period. Meanwhile
column7: results of a local survey of frequent bicycle riders indicate that 75 percent of those riders feel 'much safer' on busy roads when they ware helmets than when they don't. Clearly
column8: the best explication for the raise in bicycle-related accidents is that bicyclist take more risks now than they did ten years ago becuase they feel safer when they are wearing helmets."""

column1: 157;"A recently issued twenty-year study on headaches suffered by the residents of Mentia investigated the possible therapeutic effect of consuming salicylates.
Salicylates are members of the same chemical family as aspirin
column2: a medicine used to treat headaches. Although many foods are naturally rich in salicylates
column3: food-processing companies also add salicylates to foods as preservatives. The twenty-year study found a correlation between the rise in the commercial use of salicylates and a steady decline in the average number of headaches reported by study participants. column4: food-processing companies had just discovered that salicylates can also be used as flavor additives for foods
column5: and
column6: as a result
column7: many companies plan to do so. Based on these study results
column8: some health experts predict that residents of Mentia will suffer even fewer headaches in the future.

column3: many servers have reported that a number of customers who ask for butter do not complain when they are given margarine instead. Clearly
column4: either these customers cannot distinguish butter from margarine or they use the term 'butter' to refer to either butter or margarine. Thus
column5: to avoid the expense of purchasing butter and to increase profitability
column6: the Happy Pancake House should extend this cost-saving change to its restaurants in the southeast and northeast as well.""

column1: 262;"The following appeared in a letter to the school board in the town of Centerville.
All students should be required to take the driver's education course at Centerville High School. In the past two years

column3: some other instruction is necessary to ensure that these teenagers are safe drivers. Although there are two driving schools in Centerville
column4: parents on a tight budget cannot afford to pay for driving instruction. Therefore an effective and mandatory program sponsored by the high school is the only solution to this serious problem.""

263;"The data from a survey of high school math and science teachers show that in the district of Sanlee many of these teachers reported assigning daily homework
column2: whereas in the district of Marlee
column3: most science and math teachers reported assigning homework no more than two or three days per week. Despite receiving less frequent homework assignments
column4: Marlee students earn better grades overall and are less likely to be required to repeat a year of school than are students in Sanlee. These results call into question the usefulness of frequent homework assignments. Most likely the Marlee students have more time to concentrate on individual assignments than do the Sanlee students who have homework every day. Therefore teachers in our high schools should assign homework no more than twice a week.

column1: 266;"The following appeared as an editorial in the student newspaper of Groveton College.
To combat the recently reported dramatic rise in cheating among college students
column2: colleges and universities should adopt honor codes similar to Groveton's
column3: which calls for students to agree not to cheat in their academic endeavors and to notify a faculty member if they suspect that others have cheated. Groveton's honor code replaced an old-fashioned system in which teachers closely monitored students. Under that system
column4: teachers reported an average of thirty cases of cheating per year. The honor code has proven far more successful: in the first year it was in place
column5: students reported twenty-one cases of cheating; five years later
column6: this figure had dropped to fourteen. Moreover
column7: in a recent survey conducted by the Groveton honor council
column8: a majority of students said that they would be less likely to cheat with an honor code in place than without.""

267;"The following appeared in a memo from a budget planner for the city of Grandview.
Our citizens are well aware of the fact that while the Grandview Symphony Orchestra was struggling to succeed

column5: and attendance at the symphony's concerts-in-the-park series doubled. The symphony has also announced an increase in ticket prices for next year. Such developments indicate that the symphony can now succeed without funding from city government and we can eliminate that expense from next year's budget. Therefore
column6: we recommend that the city of Grandview eliminate its funding for the Grandview Symphony from next year's budget. By doing so
column7: we can prevent a city budget deficit without threatening the success of the symphony.""

column1: 288;"The following is a recommendation from the personnel director to the president of Acme Publishing Company.

column2: the faster you can read
column3: the more information you can absorb in a single workday. Moreover

column5: Acme would benefit greatly by requiring all of our employees to take the Easy Read course.""

289;"The following appeared in a memo from a budget planner for the city of Grandview.

column4: we recommend that the city eliminate funding for the Grandview Symphony Orchestra from next year's budget. We predict that the symphony will flourish in the years to come even without funding from the city.""

column1: 308;"The following appeared in a letter to the editor of a Relannian newspaper.
Industry analysts report that the number of dairy farms in Relanna has increased by 25 percent over the last decade. Also
column2: recent innovations in milking technology make it possible for farmers to significantly increase the efficiency of the milking process
column3: allowing them to collect more milk in less time with minimal human intervention. In fact
column4: data from the Relannian Department of Agriculture indicate that labor costs at the majority of Relannian dairy farms are actually lower now than they were ten years ago. Despite increased efficiency and lower labor costs
column5: a carton of cream — a dairy product made from milk — at the local food market costs twice as much as it did two years ago. The only explanation for this dramatic price increase is that farmers are inflating the price of cream to increase their profits.

column1: 310;"Several recent studies have shown a link between health and stair usage. One recently completed study shows that people who live in stairs-only apartment buildings (that is

column3: on average

column6: in which the patients were asked to rate several aspects of their own health (e.g.
column7: fitness

column9: susceptibility to injury
column10: etc.). The clearest explanation for these findings is that the moderate daily exercise required of residents who must use the stairs instead of elevators increases people's health and longevity.

column1: 323;"The following appeared as a memorandum from the Human Resources director at Dexter Gorman Instruments
column2: a company that manufactures saxophones.

column1: On this year's survey about work habits
column2: our employees tended to strongly agree with the idea that if they took less time to complete their assigned work
column3: the quality of their work would suffer. However
column4: we recently conducted an internal study that proves this idea wrong. Managers across several divisions identified an overtime group: the employees who worked an average of 48 or more hours per week over the past year instead of the expected 40 hours per week. We then looked at the number of documented work errors produced by all of our employees during the past year and found that the overtime group was responsible for significantly more work errors overall than their fellow employees. On the basis of these findings
column5: our recommendation to the company president is to require employees at Dexter Gorman Instruments to complete their work during the regular 40-hour work week and allow overtime only for urgent circumstances.""

column3: however
column4: has had little impact on our customers. In fact
column5: only about 2 percent of customers have complained
column6: indicating that an average of 98 people out of 100 are happy with the change. Furthermore
column7: many servers have reported that a number of customers who ask for butter do not complain when they are given margarine instead. Clearly
column8: either these customers do not distinguish butter from margarine or they use the term 'butter' to refer to either butter or margarine.""

column2: “Not everything what is learned is respected in books.” Compare and contrast knowledge gained from experiment with knowledge gained from books. In your opinion
column3: which source is more important? Why?

column1: 331;"The following appeared in a memorandum from the manager of WWAC radio station.
To reverse a decline in listener numbers
column2: our owners have decided that WWAC must change from its current rock-music format. The decline has occurred despite population growth in our listening area
column3: but that growth has resulted mainly from people moving here after their retirement. We must make listeners of these new residents. We could switch to a music format tailored to their tastes
column4: but a continuing decline in local sales of recorded music suggests limited interest in music. Instead we should change to a news and talk format
column5: a form of radio that is increasingly popular in our area.""

Compare and choose. Support with specific details.""";When people move to another country
column2: some of them decides to follow the customs of the new country. Others prefers to keep their own customs. Compare these two choices. Which one do you prefers? Support your answer with specific details.

column1: 332;"The following is a memorandum from the business manager of a television station.
Over the past year
column2: our late-night news program has devoted increased time to national news and less time to weather and local news. During this period
column3: most of the complaints received from viewers were concerned with our station's coverage of weather and local news. In addition
column4: local businesses that used to advertise during our late-night news program have canceled their advertising contracts with us. Therefore
column5: in order to attract more viewers to our news programs and to avoid losing any further advertising revenues
column6: we should expand our coverage of weather and local news on all our news programs.""

Other peoples do not judge a person’s character quickly because they believe first impressions are often wrong. Compares these two attitudes. Which attitudes do you agree with? Supporting your choice with specific examples.
333;"Two years ago
column2: radio station WCQP in Rockville decided to increase the number of call-in advice programs that it broadcast; since that time
column3: its share of the radio audience in the Rockville listening area has increased significantly. Given WCQP's recent success with call-in advice programming
column4: and citing a nationwide survey indicating that many radio listeners are quite interested in such programs
column5: the station manager of KICK in Medway recommends that KICK include more call-in advice programs in an attempt to gain a larger audience share in its listening area.

Advantages and disadvantages? Discuss with specific reasons and examples.""";Some young children spends a great amount of their time practicing sports. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of this. Use specific reasons and examples to support your answer.
334;"The following appeared in an article written by Dr. Karp
column2: an anthropologist.

column1: Twenty years ago
column2: Dr. Field
column3: a noted anthropologist
column4: visited the island of Tertia and concluded from his observations that children in Tertia were reared by an entire village rather than by their own biological parents. However
column5: my recent interviews with children living in the group of islands that includes Tertia show that these children spend much more time talking about their biological parents than about other adults in the village. This research of mine proves that Dr. Field's conclusion about Tertian village culture is invalid and thus that the observation-centered approach to studying cultures is invalid as well. The interview-centered method that my team of graduate students is currently using in Tertia will establish a much more accurate understanding of child-rearing traditions there and in other island cultures.""

To buying a car. Your friend has asked you for advice. Compare your friend's two choices and explain which one you think your friend should choose. Use specific reasons and details to support your choice.
335;"According to a recent report
column2: cheating among college and university students is on the rise. However
column3: Groveton College has successfully reduced student cheating by adopting an honor code
column4: which calls for students to agree not to cheat in their academic endeavors and to notify a faculty member if they suspect that others have cheated. Groveton's honor code replaced a system in which teachers closely monitored students; under that system
column5: teachers reported an average of thirty cases of cheating per year. In the first year the honor code was in place
column6: students reported twenty-one cases of cheating; five years later
column7: this figure had dropped to fourteen. Moreover
column8: in a recent survey
column9: a majority of Groveton students said that they would be less likely to cheat with an honor code in place than without. Thus
column10: all colleges and universities should adopt honor codes similar to Groveton's in order to decrease cheating among students.

Explain with reasons and specific examples.""";Movies are popular all over the worlds. Explain why movies are so popular. Use reasons and specific examples to supportive your answers.
336;"The following memo was published by the Welzaton City Commission.
A recent nationwide study of the effectiveness of wearing a safety helmet while bicycling indicates that ten years ago approximately 35 percent of all bicyclists reported wearing helmets
column2: whereas today that number is nearly 80 percent. Another study
column3: however
column4: cites a 200 percent increase in the number of serious accidents involving bicycles during the same period. Meanwhile
column5: results of a local survey of frequent bicycle riders indicate that 75 percent of those riders feel 'much safer' on busy roads when they wear helmets than when they don't. Clearly
column6: the best explanation for the rise in bicycle-related accidents is that bicyclists take more risks now than they did ten years ago because they feel safer when they are wearing helmets.""

Others feel like the best way to get schooled in life is through your own experiences. Break down the upsides of these two ways of learnin' 'bout life. Which one you think is better? Back up your pick with some real examples.""";Some people they believe that the best way of learn about life is by listen to the advices of family and friends. Other people believe that the best way of learning about life is through experience personal. Compare the advantages of these two different ways of learning about life. Which way do you think is preferable? Use specific examples to support your preference.
337;"The following memorandum is from the president of Primo Doll Manufacturing
column2: Inc.

column1: According to a survey last year of parents who purchased the Elkie
column2: our most popular doll
column3: 90 percent reported that although their children were extremely satisfied with the doll's features
column4: the doll quickly wore out with use. In a follow-up survey of the same parents
column5: 80 percent reported that they would recommend a more durable version of the doll to their friends. In response to these surveys
column6: we have created the Elkie-Advanced Doll
column7: which has similar features to the original Elkie Doll but is manufactured using the same higher quality materials used by Optima Doll Manufacturing
column8: our most successful competitor. Because parents can now purchase the beloved Elkie doll and be sure that it won't quickly wear out with use
column9: we predict that our profits will exceed those of Optima Doll Manufacturing this year.""
